item.title: ♪ ♪ That good ship and true was a bone to be chewed, when the gales of November came early ♪ ♪
item.description:
This was supposed to be posted yesterday on November 10th, but I only finished it now. It’s only 3am, so I’m counting it as yesterday still. I know that I’ve been gone for a while. I’m still sick and fatigued all the time. I don’t have the stamina to make my usual detailed posts. This one will also be cutting some corners as well, but not many. . Anyway… Fifty years ago today, one of the greatest maritime tragedies and mysteries took place. The Edmund Fitzgerald was a cargo ship that was caught in an extremely ugly storm on the Great Lakes. After sending a distress signal, all contact was suddenly cut off. The ship had sunk, taking all 29 crew members on board with it. She was even the subject of a song by Gordon Lightfoot: https://youtu.be/FuzTkGyxkYI?si=j2XWS7twKC9SYyJv Despite numerous investigations, nobody really knows what happened during the time between the last radio transmission and the sinking. There have been many theories ranging from a failure to secure the hatches to a rogue wave suddenly taking it over. I’m not going to be able to answer the question of what happened, because I have no idea myself. But I hope that this will be informative to those who don’t know the wreck very well.
The Edmund Fitzgerald was a cargo ship that typically carried a raw material known as taconite pellets. This is less relevant to the sinking of the ship, but for anyone that is curious about taconite pellets: Taconite is a low-grade iron ore. It was originally viewed as the iron equivalent of EA-Nasir’s shitty copper, and not used at all. However, over time, continuous mining made high grade iron harder and harder to come by. In fact, this scarcity was threatening to end the iron industry. That’s when scientists turned to taconite. Through much experimentation, scientists found a way to separate the iron from the taconite to make it usable for steel production. The process is a little complicated, but the general steps involved: 1.) Mining the talconite 2.) Crushing the rock until it’s a fine powder 3.) Using magnetism to separate the iron from the talcite 4.) Rolling this concentrated powder into clay balls the size of a marble 5.) Heat treating these little balls until they are white hot. 6.) When they cool, they become hard taconite pellets that are loaded onto cargo ships and shipped across the Great Lakes to steel manufacturers to be melted down into steel.
This is a blueprint of the SS Edmund Fitzgerald. It was the longest of the cargo ships to be sailing at that time. The wheelhouse was at the bow of the ship while the crew’s quarters and dining hall were in the stern next to the engine room. The long stretch between the bow and the stern was where the cargo was held. Each container was closed tight with metal levers(?) called “hatchets.” They acted like claws gripping the lids of the holding containers. I added a small image with a closeup of the hatchets, and I colored them red to make it more visible.
I need to add a disclaimer here: I was personally taught that longer cargo ships are now seen as terrible design flaws than they were back then. However, I’m beginning to doubt the truthfulness of that statement. Still, this is how it was explained to me: A long design allowed them to carry more cargo, but it also made them weaker to rough seas because their middle section made for a stress point. The high seas could basically karate chop these ships in half. The long designs also allowed the end of the ship to hit the bottom of the lake between each massive wave. When striking the bottom, the force of impact causes that section of the ship to break, and then it sinks.
Like so. One of these scenarios most likely sunk the Edmund Fitzgerald as well, though we don’t know which one. What we DO know are the events leading up to it. We
Here’s a VERY simplified version of what we know for sure. I’m sorry for all of the dots separating the timeline, there’s not a feature for multiple spaces between paragraphs yet. I hate it just as much as you do. . > At 2:30pm on November 9th, 1975, the Edmund Fitzgerald sailed through ugly weather to reach its offload destination. . > As time went on, the weather got worse, but it wasn’t bad enough for a couple of captains to delay their transport plans, as they had experience sailing rough seas. . > At an unspecified time, Captain Cooper saw the Fitzgerald sail too close to the shoal near Caribou Island. . > At 3:30 pm, the Edmund Fitzgerald sent out a radio message to the Arthur M. Anderson: “Anderson, this is the Fitzgerald. I have a fence rail down, two vents lost or damaged, and a list. I’m checking down. Will you stay by me till I get to Whitefish?” Cooper asked if he had his pumps going and he said: “Yes. Both of them.” Both captains set sail for Whitefish Point, and kept in regular communication about their navigation. This part was uneventful. . > At 5:20pm, Cooper reported his location to have 58 knot winds and gushes of wind that were as high as 70 knots, with tall waves ranging from 18 - 25ft . > 6:55pm - The Arthur M. Anderson is hit with two massive waves. One of these waves is so strong that it temporarily pushes the bow into the water. He would later say this: “Then the Anderson just raised up and shook herself off of all that water – barrooff – just like a big dog. Another wave just like the first one or bigger hit us again. I watched those two waves head down the lake towards the Fitzgerald, and I think those were the two that sent her under.” . > Between 6:55pm - 7:10pm, the Anderson keeps losing sight of the Edmund Fitzgerald on their ship’s radar because the waves were so violent that it interfered with the radar system. . > 7:10pm - First Mate Morgan Clark of the Arthur M. Anderson makes one last call to the Captain of the Edmund Fitzgerald. Clark: Fitzgerald, this is the Anderson. Have you checked down? McSorely: Yes, we have. Clark: Fitzgerald, we are about 10 miles behind you, and gaining about 1 1/2 miles per hour. Fitzgerald, there is a target 19 miles ahead of us. So the target would be 9 miles on ahead of you. McSorely: “Well, Am I going to clear? Clark: Yes, he is going to pass to the west of you McSorely: Well, fine. Clark: By the way, Fitzgerald, how are you making out with your problems? McSorely: We are holding our own. Clark: Okay, fine, I’ll be talking to you later. . > 7:10 - 7:15 - the Edmund Fitzgerald continues to come in and out of the radar’s detection . > 7:15pm - The Edmund Fitzgerald disappears from the radar for the last time and doesn’t reappear. It’s assumed that’s when she sank, taking all 29 crew members on board with her.
After the weather was safe enough to do a more thorough search of Lake Superior, the wreck site of the Edmund Fitzgerald was finally discovered in May 1976. An initial submersible investigation was done from a submersible that was controlled from the surface that took pictures and video. These were their initial findings.
I put together some images of the wreckage, though these are from other dives. The images from the first investigation either haven’t been released to the public, or I couldn’t find them.
This is a drawing of the locations of the bow and stern of the ship. I’ve always wondered what happened to the piece of the middle section that seems to have just disappeared.
An artist’s rendition of a submersible exploring the wreck site. I couldn’t find their name, which surprised me.
That report was not received well. The surviving loved ones were angry at the accusations. Other experts felt that this conclusion was just a lazy attempt to close the investigation by blaming the perished crew that can’t defend themselves. Since that initial dive, four other dives took place, including one to retrieve the ship’s bell in 1995. None of these dives had concrete results, but there was a forensic investigation done in 2018 based off of the footage from the 1994 and 1995 dives. They came to this conclusion about the hatch covers: “If the Fitzgerald had failed due to the hatch covers amidships getting blown in, and / or the hull girder breaking, then the condition of the two forward most hatch covers located just behind the pilot house remains unexplained.”
Aside from failure in the hatch covers, the two main theories are that the ship either struck the bottom of the lake and snapped in half, or she bottomed out.
I don’t even know how to make a visual for this, because I barely understand it, but it definitely makes sense for an entire domino set of terrible things to come crashing down in such a rapid sinking.
This was Captain Bernie Cooper’s theory on how the Edmund Fitzgerald sank.
During a dive to the wreck of the Fitzgerald in 1994, the remains of one crew member were discovered near the bow. He was partially dressed in coveralls and wearing a cork lifejacket. However, they couldn’t identify him. The surviving families were notified, and they chose to leave the body there. Fred Shannon apparently said that the cork life-vest proved that the captain was aware that the ship could possibly sink, but that’s a dumb hypothesis. I’ll get to that in a moment. I did see the picture of the body, as well as the documentary where it came from - in a link that has since been deleted. I originally avoided it like the plague because the surviving families didn’t want it released - but I decided to view the documentary for more information on the wreck. The picture of the body was so blurry, you couldn’t make out anything. It was also distorted by all of the silt that was now floating about due to being disturbed by the divers and submersibles. I couldn’t make out a life vest. All I saw was silt.
Back to the cork life vest… This is what happens when you let a retired police officer/business man play pretend as a scientific explorer: they make stupid statements. Normally I try to be respectful of people who make mistakes in logic due to an inaccurate understanding of the situation. We’ve all come to a wrong conclusion based on misunderstood information at least once in our lives. This time was different, because it was an invasive investigation under false pretenses. Fred Shannon was a retired police officer and a businessman. He was never a scientist, or archaeological expert. He had no background in engineering, or anything relevant to the sinking of a ship. He provided the submersibles, at the chagrin of the surviving families. He went down there, rooted around, found a body, and made sure to get up-close footage of it to publish in a book and documentary, and presented it as him documenting scientific evidence as if he actually understood the results. That entire expedition made him seem smarter than he actually was, and his idiotic conclusion that made the life vest a bigger deal that it was is a representation of that. The truth: it is maritime protocol to wear a life-vest in bad weather. EVERY sailor on rough seas would do this. Wearing a life-vest doesn’t provide any further clues on the sinking. It just means that the crew that was on deck had common sense.
This is just a hypothesis by a random nerd, but I actually think that the reason that there weren’t any other remains found around the ship is because they were in the stern section of the vessel, where the crew’s quarters were. “Don’t let nobody on deck.” Was heard on the radio, which I think means that the rest of the crew was riding out the storm in the ship, while the captain was still at the wheel house. I firmly believe that the set of remains that were discovered were the captain’s. I believe that when the ship sank, he was thrown out of the wheelhouse and then forcefully smashed into the lake floor next to the bow. As for the other poor souls, submersibles have checked the living quarters before, but didn’t find anything. However, I haven’t read anything about the engine rooms or the boiler rooms. This actually makes me think of the sinking of the RMS Titanic. One of the things that the crew on the Titanic were DESPERATELY trying to prevent was the icy ocean water touching the steaming hot boilers. They knew that when that inevitably happened, it would cause an epic explosion. Something that I’ve wondered about is if there was a possibility that a few of the men ran to the boiler room to try to protect it from the incoming cold water. This is all conjecture from someone who doesn’t know a damn thing about ships, but I wanted to share my thoughts on it anyway.
We’ll never know for sure what happened that night. Time has almost certainly taken its toll on the ship at this point, and the surviving families of those who perished understandably want the wreck to be left alone. It’s unlikely that there will be another authorized expedition to the wreck, and that’s okay. I don’t want to come off as shaming grieving people for wanting closure. I would love for there to be another investigation one day to confirm that a failure to secure the hatches wasn’t to blame, but I also understand the desire to just leave it alone at this point. My condolences to everyone who lost someone in the Sinking of the Edmund Fitzgerald, and may those who perished that night rest in peace.
Sinking of the Edmund Fitzgerald: https://shipwreckmuseum.com/the-fateful-journey/ Edmund Fitzgerald Infographic (I would’ve added this to my post but my phone wouldn’t let me): http://www.codex99.com/unclassified/images/fitzgerald/infographic_lg.jpg Taconite Pellets: https://www.dnr.state.mn.us/education/geology/digging/taconite.html Cargo Ship Sinking infographic: https://share.google/RaB6xRm6sGrZQjBZX The 2018 Forensic Investigation: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/323691614_A_Forensic_Investigation_Of_The_Breakup_And_Sinking_Of_The_Great_Lakes_Iron_Ore_Carrier_Edmund_Fitzgerald_November_10th_1975_Using_Modern_Naval_Architecture_Tools_And_Techniques The 1977 Marine Accident Report: https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Reports/MAR7803.pdf Captain Bernie Cooper’s Theory: https://youtu.be/3VXY6tuZ5eU?si=CCQVF1NjpA5CWDUv 2025 Documentary on the Edmund Fitzgerald: https://youtu.be/8KpkceTklu0?si=5t4DYW_bcGoQNCqS Last Transmission: https://ssedmundfitzgerald.org/fitz-timeline About Fred Shannon: https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/05/us/photos-in-book-on-shipwreck-upset-families-of-the-victims.html Here’s an interesting article about the morality of diving to the wreckage: https://www.mlive.com/news/2025/11/a-wreck-apart-50-years-later-the-edmund-fitzgerald-legend-endures.html

item.description: So I know in the past I've done dumps, and this is more for people who get notifications when I post, but I'm thinking about posting smaller amounts over larger periods of time. Like multiple in a day versus 50 in a week. I just want to give a heads up as I figure it could annoy the living shit out of some of you. If it goes well, if I can stick with this, some days I might be posting a lot. and at like all hours of the available day so like 24 hours who knows when I'm going to post but it might be a lot so, yeah. I want to say that I hope you guys are doing well, but I feel like it would be more appropriate to say that I hope you're finding time to rest. And I hope you have days, or at least a moment that you smile, like really really smile and think about the fact that you're smiling and feel alive and feel grateful that you get to experience that feeling again, and I hope that you can hold on to those moments, and I hope they can get you through. -comet
item.dc:creator: iamthecomet

item.title: Return of the Meme: 1522 (Bene Jazzerit)
item.description:
Let's get this bread, I guess.
Fell asleep at work. Fuck. Fuck this body. Probably going to get fired.
Nothing works, it seems.
I may as well face it: im worthless, my body is shit, my brain is shit, and nothing is ever going to get better and now I dont even have insurance.
Sure, ill die in another Norman attack on Dyrrachium, whatever.
I dont know what this is like anymore.
I hate that my body and brain won't keep me awake. I hate they get thirsty for water and lust. I hate having desire. I hate only suffering. I hate wanting to have better things that I am not allowed to experience because of either late stage capitalism or my own anxiety of existence. I hate existence. I just want someone to take me outside and end things.
Pretty sure we all do, buddy, on all our own asses. What makes hers special, you want to use it as a hot wheels track? Do you even think they'd let you? They won't want anything to do with you.
Also my own brain.
One of my favorite Pratchett quotes.
Ah, Bene Jazzerit.
I literally in my depression went to bed at 7pm last night and even after almost 11 hours of sleep, i right now can barely stay awake. I need to spend more time in places with mass shootings so someone can tag me as bycatch.
I haven't re-read Sourcery in probably 15 years. Probably the Pratchett book I'm least familiar with.
"But unfortunately society demands I do this, because if I don't, I can't afford to live because I live in a country that's actually 17 oligarchs in a trench coat who wish they could live without us and want us to suffer for a crumb of bread."
That's my secret: there's always a panic attack coming.
it's the only thing I'm good at and I wish I could actually get paid for it.
Spite isn't cutting it anymore. It really isn't. Hell, even Pippin is barely cutting it anymore.
Pippin Tax Today's message from Pippin: [noncommital grunt] ______ 1) Are you on the run to a safe place and passing through Arizona on your way to safer grounds? My apartment is open to you to crash at, and it is a safe space. Pippin and I will make you a meal and gladly share tea, wine, or mead with you. 2) Hey! Take your meds with a full glass of water, please. Do it for Pippin, or Space Mom, or better yet, do it for yourself. 3) Ĝefeloað wē. We will carry on. 4) all funds from the sales of items at these two links will be sent to support charities aiding to fight for Trans rights in the US (not just T-shirts!) https://www.teepublic.com/t-shirt/74812801-all-conures-are-anarchists https://www.teepublic.com/t-shirt/74811778-whiptail-pride 5) Since multiple people have requested this over the last two weeks or so, my ko-fi is: https://ko-fi.com/codyandpippin

item.title: MRW my psychiatrist that I’ve had for 29 years starts reading some of my files to me but they are dating all the way back from 1996.
item.description:
Ef am I ever cringy.
Today he was like “oh remember when you dated Justin?”
Yes holy fuck can we stop please. (TBH I was just thinking about this yesterday and how cringey it is to have your first kiss be with a boy you met in the psych ward. Plus it was in the trashiest part of the city.)
Ew ew ew. But then he reads me how I used to talk about myself when I was a depressed teenager and I feel sad for that kid.
Then he reads me some weirdo stuff I said again.
But as he’s writing the letter to pass off my care to my family doctor and my therapist, he says what a gift it was to be able to work with this wonderful woman in her formative years.
His reactions during my two major depressions. The first one I almost offed myself.
The second one he was about to retire but then put it off because I was drowning and fast.
The moments I am the most thankful for are him being there during a crisis. I called him when I was living in S.Korea and having severe panic attacks (so bad I lost 50lbs in a year) and he called me back from an airport in Toronto while he was on his way to Israel. Like…that’s commitment. He’s been in the trenches with me, cheered me on and celebrated my successes. He’s always been a proud dadchiatrist.
I am incredibly fortunate to have had the chance to be cared for like this. I was in the right place at the right time and I never paid a cent for it because I’m Canadian. I’m also not taking it too badly because, it’s not a total cut off. I will no longer be in his care, but I’m still allowed to text him when cool things happen and invite him to my 50th birthday or god forbid I ever date someone and get married. He’ll likely be there to celebrate. So it’s more like I’m graduating from needing a psychiatrist to just needing a psychologist. Wooooot.
For reading this far.
item.dc:creator: MadameRainbowPants

item.title: No judgement
item.description: No judgement, but asking for free food or what not because I’m a veteran on Veterans Day just doesn’t sit well with me.
